DT Article
TI Study on four new species of the genus Atrichopogon Kieffer (Diptera:
   Ceratopogonidae) from Haldia under coastal region of east Medinipur
   district (West Bengal), India.
AU Sinha, Saswati
   Dasgupta, Sujit Kumar
SO Journal of Natural History - Kalyani
VL 7
IS 1
PS 29-34
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of biting midges of the genus Atrichopogon: A. arduus,
   A. subinfamis, A. minibrevicomis and A semibrevicomis are described from
   the coastal region of East Medinipur district (West Bengal), India. With
   these present four, the number of species is raised to 54 in India.
C1 Sinha, Saswati; Post Graduate Department of Zoology, Bethune College,
   Kolkata 700006, India, India.
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Atrichopogon arduus; Atrichopogon minibrevicornis; Atrichopogon
   semibrevicornis; Atrichopogon subinfamis [West Bengal /  / New species].
   
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Ceratopogonidae
OR Atrichopogon - Kieffer (Ceratopogonidae): [Diagnosis, Male & female, p.
   30]. 
   Atrichopogon arduus (Ceratopogonidae): [Sp nov, West Bengal, P. 30]. 
   Atrichopogon minibrevicornis (Ceratopogonidae): [Sp nov, West Bengal, P.
   32]. 
   Atrichopogon semibrevicornis (Ceratopogonidae): [Sp nov, West Bengal, P.
   33]. 
   Atrichopogon subinfamis (Ceratopogonidae): [Sp nov, West Bengal, P. 31].

PT J
AN ZOOR14711081622
DT Article
TI Reassessment of Lower Palaeozoic geology west of the Catombal Range,
   Wellington region, central New South Wales.
AU Percival, Ian G. (ian.percival@industry.nsw.gov.au) 
   Quinn, Cameron
SO Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales
VL 132
PS 221-235
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New palaeontological discoveries and revised mapping of Lower Palaeozoic
   sedimentary rocks located west of the Catombal Range, between Wellington
   and Yeoval in central New South Wales, underpins a new model for the
   Ordovician and Silurian geological history of this region. West of the
   abandoned Gunners Dam gold mine, large blocks of deep-water siltstones,
   spiculite, and laminated chert contain Late Ordovician graptolites,
   including Dicellograptus and Climacograptus (associated with the
   dendroid Dendrograptus). Along strike to the north near Arthurville,
   west of Wellington, lensoidal outcrops of sandstone, conglomerate and
   limestone (previously assigned to the Oakdale Formation) contain a new
   brachiopod genus and species, described here as Narrawaella
   wellingtonense, that is associated with conodonts and lingulate
   brachiopods of Late Ordovician (Katian) age. We interpret all these
   Upper Ordovician rocks as allochthonous, having been redeposited into
   Silurian sediments of the Cowra Trough. Similar occurrences of
   allochthonous Upper Ordovician limestones at Eurimbla and Cumnock to the
   south, and comparable deposits previously recognised in the Hill End
   Trough further to the east, suggest this model is widely applicable to
   areas peripheral to the Macquarie Arc in central New South Wales.
C1 Percival, Ian G.; Geological Survey of New South Wales, WB Clarke
   Geoscience Centre, 947-953 Londonderry Road, Londonderry, NSW 2753,
   Australia, Australia.
EM ian.percival@industry.nsw.gov.au
OI Percival, Ian/0000-0001-5161-2021
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0370-047X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Australasia; Australia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Animalia [Fossil assemblages / Fossil assemblage composition /
   Systematics] [New South Wales / Wellington region, Catombal Range /
   stratigraphical distribution] [Palaeozoic / Lower Palaeozoic / ]. 
   Dendrograptus; Graptolithina [New South Wales / Wellington region,
   Catombal Range / stratigraphical distribution; systematics] [Ordovician
   / Late Ordovician / ]. 
   Narrawaella [Silurian /  / New South Wales; redeposition from Ordovician
   strata] [Ordovician /  / New genus]. 
   Narrawaella wellingtonense [New South Wales /  / new species]
   [Ordovician /  / ]. 
TN Brachiopods; Graptolites; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Brachiopoda, Graptolithina
OR Animalia: [Fossil]. 
   Graptolithina (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
   Narrawaella - Percival 2011 (Brachiopoda): [Gen nov, Of family
   Tritoechiidae, Type species Narrawaella wellingtonense, p. 230,
   Ordovician; Fossil]. 
   Narrawaella wellingtonense (Brachiopoda): [Sp nov, New South Wales,
   Ordovician, P. 230; Fossil]. 
   Dendrograptus - Hall 1858 (Graptolithina): [Fossil].

AN ZOOR14711077759
DT Article
TI The spider genus Hersilia in Thailand, with descriptions of two new
   species (Araneae, Hersiliidae).
AU Dankittipakul, Pakawin (pakawin@gmail.com) 
   Singtripop, Tippawan
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 118
IS 2
PS 207-221
PD juin 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The spider genus Hersilia in Thailand, with descriptions of two new
   species (Araneae, Hersiliidae). - Our examination of a hersiliid spider
   collection from Thailand revealed eight species of which two species are
   new (Hersilia serrata sp. n. [male], [female], H. thailandica sp. n.,
   [male]). Extended geographic ranges are recorded for H. sundaica Baehr &
   Baehr, 1993 and H. martensi Baehr & Baehr, 1993, which are reported from
   Thailand for the first time. H. asiatica Song & Zheng, 1982, which was
   previously documented from northeastern Thailand, is now also found in
   northern and southern Thailand. A substantial number of females from
   Thailand are similar to H. striata Wang & Yin, 1985, previously known
   from China, but can be distinguished by slight differences in their
   genital morphology.
C1 Dankittipakul, Pakawin; Chiang Mai Univ, Fac Sci, Chiang Mai, 50200,
   Thailand, Thailand.
EM pakawin@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0035-418X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   Hersilia asiatica [Thailand / Chiang Mai, Nakhon Sri Thrammarat &
   Phetchabun / New record]. 
   Hersilia martensi; Hersilia sundaica [Thailand /  / New record]. 
   Hersilia serrata; Hersilia thailandica [Thailand /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

   Hersilia martensi (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Hersilia serrata (Araneae): [Sp nov, Thailand, P. 213]. 
   Hersilia sundaica (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Hersilia thailandica (Araneae): [Sp nov, Thailand, P. 216].

PT J
AN ZOOR14711077760
DT Article
TI Two new species of Amynthas (Clitellata: Megascolecidae) from lettuce
   fields of Mt. Taebaek, Korea.
AU Dankittipakul, Pakawin (pakawin@gmail.com) 
   Hong, Yong
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 118
IS 2
PS 223-230
PD juin 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Amynthas (Clitellata: Megascolecidae) from lettuce
   fields of Mt. Taebaek, Korea. - Two new species of earthworms were found
   in a survey of lettuce cultivation fields, created by slash and burn.
   Amynthas hasamensis sp. n. and Amynthas samgaki sp. n. have simple
   intestinal caeca and no genital markings. Amynthas hasamensis sp. n.
   keys to the hawayanus group in Sims & Easton (1972) with three pairs of
   spermathecae in VI, VII, and VIII. Its male field areas in XVIII are
   complex with paired oval male discs bearing two transverse ridges with
   seminal grooves between the ridges. Amynthas samgaki sp. n. keys to the
   morrisi group with two pairs of spermathecae in VI and VII, and has a
   male field with large egg-shaped raised pads with transverse seminal
   grooves.
C1 Dankittipakul, Pakawin; Chonbuk Natl Univ, Coll Agr & Life Sci, Jeonju,
   561756, South Korea, South Korea.
EM pakawin@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0035-418X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Amynthas hasamensis; Amynthas samgaki [South Korea /  / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Oligochaeta
OR Amynthas hasamensis (Oligochaeta): [Sp nov, South Korea, P. 224]. 
   Amynthas samgaki (Oligochaeta): [Sp nov, South Korea, P. 226]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14711077760

DT Article
TI A new Scutpelecopsis Marusik & Gnelitsa from Romania (Araneae,
   Linyphiidae, Erigoninae).
AU Duma, Ioan (ioan.duma@gmail.com) 
   Tanasevitch, Andrei V.
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 118
IS 2
PS 251-256
PD juin 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new Scutpelecopsis Marusik & Gnelitsa from Romania (Araneae,
   Linyphiidae, Erigoninae). - A new species, S. loricata sp. n., is
   described from the southern Carpathians, Romania, differing from the two
   known congeners by details of the palp and epigyne conformation. All
   records of Scutpelecopsis krausi (Wunderlich, 1980) from the Caucasus
   actually refer to S. wunderlichi Marusik & Gnelitsa, 2009, thus the
   known distribution of S. krausi remains restricted to the type locality
   in Macedonia.
C1 Duma, Ioan; W Univ Timisoara, Fac Chem Biol Geog, Pestalozzi 16,
   Timisoara, Timis County, 300115, Romania, Romania.
EM ioan.duma@gmail.com
RI Duma, Ioan/F-7966-2011; Tanasevitch, Andrei/O-7401-2018
OI Tanasevitch, Andrei/0000-0002-9116-606X
SC Zoology
SN 0035-418X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Scutpelecopsis krausi [Macedonia /  / Distribution]. 
   Scutpelecopsis loricata [Romania /  / New species]. 
   Scutpelecopsis wunderlichi [Eurasia / Caucasus / Distribution]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Scutpelecopsis krausi (Araneae). 
   Scutpelecopsis loricata (Araneae): [Sp nov, Romania, P. 252]. 
   Scutpelecopsis wunderlichi (Araneae).

DT Article
TI Centrorhynchidae (Acanthocephala) including the description of new
   species of Centrorhynchus from birds from the Cote d'Ivoire, Africa.
AU Smales, Lesley R. (l.warner@cqu.edu.au) 
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 118
IS 2
PS 307-318
PD juin 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Centrorhynchidae (Acanthocephala) including the description of new
   species of Centrorhynchus from birds from the Cote d'Ivoire, Africa. -
   Centrorhynchidae, including Centrorhynchus chabaudi, Golvan, 1958, and
   two new species C. mariauxi and C. halcyonicola are reported from the
   Cote d'Ivoire, for the first time. The new species are distinguished
   from congenerics by a combination of proboscis armature and the
   morphometrics of the male reproductive system.
C1 Smales, Lesley R.; S Australian Museum, Parasitol Sect, Adelaide, SA,
   5000, Australia, Australia.

DT Article
TI Heptapterus mbya (Siluriformes: Heptapteridae), a new species of catfish
   from the Parana river basin, in Argentina.
AU de las Mercedes Azpelicueta, Maria (azpeli@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Aguilera, Gaston
   Marcos Mirande, Juan
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 118
IS 2
PS 319-327
PD juin 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Heptapterus mbya (Siluriformes: Heptapteridae), a new species of catfish
   from the Parana river basin, in Argentina. - We describe a new species
   of heptapterid catfish of the genus Heptapterus from the streams
   Cuna-Piru, Azul, and Moreno, in the province of Misiones, Argentina.
   Heptapterus mbya sp. n. is distinguished from all other congeners by
   dark plumbeous body and a low number of anal-fin rays that are branched
   (11-12) out of a total number of 15-17 anal fin rays, a large eye
   (13.8-17.9 % of HL), prepectoral distance 31.9-37.8 % of SL, distance
   between the last dorsal-fin ray and the adipose-fin origin 5.24-8.33 To
   of SL, adipose-fin base 47.4-58.5 % of SL, 13 principal caudal-fin rays,
   and 10-13 gill rakers on the first arch.
C1 de las Mercedes Azpelicueta, Maria; Museo La Plata, Div Zool
   Vertebrados, La Plata, RA-1900, Argentina, Argentina.
EM azpeli@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Zoology
SN 0035-418X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Heptapterus mbya [Argentina /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Siluriformes, Pimelodidae
OR Heptapterus mbya (Pimelodidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 320].

TI On Sicilian Typhloreicheia (Holdhaus, 1924) of the 'praecox group' with
   description of a new species (Coleoptera Carabidae: Scaritinae).
FT Note sulle Typhloreicheia (Holdhaus, 1924) siciliane del 'gruppo
   praecox' con descrizione di una nuova specie (Coleoptera Carabidae:
   Scaritinae).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
   Baviera, Cosimo
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 118
IS 2
PS 329-343
PD juin 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB On Sicilian Typhloreicheia (Holdhaus, 1924) of the "praecox group" with
   description of a new species (Coleoptera Carabidae: Scaritinae). -
   Taxonomic status of taxa belonging to Typhloreicheia "praecox group" is
   discussed and a new species from western Sicily differs from all the
   other known taxa in the external morphology and its aedeagus shape is
   described. Also included are images, dichotomic keys and distribution
   maps for all the sicilian species.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Via Gianfilippo Braccini 7, Florence, I-50141, Italy,
   Italy.

PT J
AN ZOOR14711080581
DT Article
TI The bivalve Divariscintilla toyohiwakensis n. sp. (Heterodonta:
   Galeommatidae) from Japan, a commensal with a mantis shrimp.
AU Yamashita, Hiroyoshi
   Haga, Takuma
   Lutzen, Jorgen (jlutzen@bio.ku.dk) 
SO Venus (Tokyo)
VL 69
IS 3-4
PS 123-133
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We describe the morphology of a new species of the bivalve family
   Galeommatidae, Divariscintilla tovohiwakensis n. sp., which lives in the
   burrows of the mantis shrimp Acanthosquilla acanthocarpus at Oshinden,
   Nakatsu, Oita Prefecture, Kyushu, Japan. An unpaired median tentacle and
   three paired tentacles issue from the mid-mantle fold, which partially
   covers the shell. A single flower-like organ originates on the anterior
   surface of the visceral mass. A byssal adhesive gland is observed on the
   most posterior part of the foot. This is the first record of the genus
   in Japan and the North Pacific Ocean.
C1 Lutzen, Jorgen; Biological Institute, University of Copenhagen,
   Universitetsparken 15, DK-2100, Copenhagen, Denmark, Denmark.
EM jlutzen@bio.ku.dk
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0042-3580
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Acanthosquilla acanthocarpus [Nest and burrow fauna / Divariscintilla
   toyohiwakensis (Mollusca) / New burrow associate species] [North Pacific
   / Japan / New burrow associated molluscan species]. 
   Divariscintilla [North Pacific / Japan / New record]. 
   Divariscintilla toyohiwakensis [Nest and burrow fauna / Acanthosquilla
   acanthocarpus (Crustacea) / New burrow associate species] [North Pacific
   / Japan / New species from crustacean burrow]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Hoplocarida, Stomatopoda, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Heterodonta, Veneroida,
   Galeommatoidea
OR Acanthosquilla acanthocarpus (Stomatopoda). 
   Divariscintilla (Galeommatoidea): [New record]. 
   Divariscintilla toyohiwakensis (Galeommatoidea): [Sp nov, Japan
   (marine), Burrow associate of Acanthosquilla acanthocarpus (Crustacea),
   p. 124].

TI Another new Calyptogena clam from deep-sea seeps off the Sanriku Coast
   and in Sagami Bay, Japan (Mollusca: Bivalvia).
AU Okutani, Takashi (okutani@jamstec.go.jp) 
   Kojima, Shigeaki
   Kawato, Masaru
   Seo, Eriko
   Fujikura, Katsunori
SO Venus (Tokyo)
VL 69
IS 3-4
PS 135-144
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Among deep-sea chemosynthesis-based communities with large-scale
   Calyptogena soyoae/okutanii aggregations in the Off Matsushima Island
   seep site, another new vesicomyid species, C. fortunata, was discovered.
   The analyzed DNA data of these specimens correspond to those from the
   Off Sanriku coast site, in spite of the fact that shell characters of
   specimens from both localities show a slight difference, probably
   representing phenotypic variability.

AN ZOOR14710071256
DT Article
TI A new Puercan (early Paleocene) hyopsodontid 'condylarth' from New
   Mexico.
AU Williamson, Thomas E. (thomas.williamson@state.nm.us) 
   Weil, Anne
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 56
IS 2
PS 247-255
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Isolated cheek teeth from the late Puercan (early Paleocene) Split Lip
   Flats local fauna, from the head of Willow Wash, Nacimiento Formation,
   San Juan Basin, represent a new genus and species of hyopsodontid
   "condylarth", Chacomylus sladei. The teeth are small, bunodont, and are
   remarkable for the enlargement of the protocone, pronounced
   exodaenodonty, and high degree of attritional wear caused by transverse
   shearing or grinding. Although C. sladei bears a superficial resemblance
   to the apheliscine apheliscid Gingerichia, a preliminary phylogenetic
   analysis confirms that it is a hyopsodontid, closely related to the
   Puercan hyopsodontids Valenia wilsoni and Litomylus orthronepius.
C1 Williamson, Thomas E.; New Mexico Museum Nat Hist & Sci, 1801 Mt Rd NW,
   Albuquerque, NM 87104, USA, USA.
EM thomas.williamson@state.nm.us
RI Williamson, Thomas/AAW-9320-2020
OI Williamson, Thomas/0000-0002-2856-9632
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0567-7920; 1732-2421
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Chacomylus [Palaeocene /  / New genus].

DT Article
TI New dryolestidan mammal from the Hauterivian-Barremian transition of the
   Iberian Peninsula.
AU Cuenca-Bescos, Gloria (cuencag@unizar.es) 
   Badiola, Ainara
   Canudo, Jose I.
   Gasca, Jose M.
   Moreno-Azanza, Miguel
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 56
IS 2
PS 257-267
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Crusafontia amoae sp. nov. (Dryolestida, Stem Cladotheria) is
   represented by two isolated upper molars (M4 or M5 and M6 or M7) from
   the terminal Hauterivian-basal Barremian (Early Cretaceous) of the El
   Caste liar Formation (Galve, Spain). The molars have a deep ectoflexus,
   a distinct metacone, a continuous metacrista, and an antero-lingually
   placed paracone. They differ from the molars of the other species of the
   genus, Crusafontia cuencana, by their larger size, by their outsized
   parastyle, by the pointed lingual slope of the paracone, their more
   symmetrical appearance with a deep ectoflexus in occlusal view, and the
   well-developed metacone. Revision of three isolated teeth previously
   attributed to Crusafontia cuencana suggests that instead of being upper
   premolars belonging to Crusafontia cuencana they in fact belong to
   Pocamus pepelui, of the stem cladotherian superorder Zatheria, probably
   "peramuran". As such, the stem Cladotheria record from the Early
   Cretaceous of the Iberian Peninsula is composed of two dryolestids
   (Crusafontia amoae and Crusafontia cuencana) and one zatherian (Pocamus
   pepelui).

DT Article
TI Aspects of diversity in early Antarctic penguins.
AU Jadwiszczak, Piotr (piotrj@uwb.edu.pl) 
   Mors, Thomas
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 56
IS 2
PS 269-277
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Penguin bones from the Eocene La Meseta Formation (Seymour Island,
   Antarctic Peninsula) constitute the only extensive fossil record of
   Antarctic Sphenisciformes. Here, we synonymize some of the recognized
   genera (Anthropornis with Orthopteryx, Delphinornis with Ichtyopteryx)
   and species (Anthropornis nordenskjoeldi with Orthopteryx gigas,
   Delphinornis gracilis with Ichtyopteryx gracilis). Moreover, we suggest
   that Antarctic species of Anthropornis and Palaeeudyptes, so-called
   giant penguins, may in fact comprise only one species each instead of
   two, based on evidence of well-marked sexual dimorphism. We also present
   new estimates of body mass based on femora testifying to the impressive
   scope of interspecific body-size variation in Eocene Antarctic penguins.

   20B, Bialystok, PL-15950, Poland, Poland.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic implications of the residual colour patterns of ampullinid
   gastropods and their contribution to the discrimination from naticids.
AU Caze, Bruno (bruno.caze@mnhn.fr) 
   Merle, Didier
   Le Meur, Mathicu
   Pacaud, Jean-Michel
   Ledon, Daniel
   Saint Martin, Jean-Paul
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 56
IS 2
PS 329-347
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The diversity of residual colour patterns is revealed for the first time
   in the European fossil Ampullinidae. The colour patterns were studied
   under Ultraviolet (UV) light in approximately 3100 specimens belonging
   to 83 species, 12 genera (Ampullina, Globularia, Crommium, Amaurellina,
   Pachycrommium, Amauropsina, Ampullonatica, Eocernina, Ampullinopsis,
   Vanikoropsis, Pictavia, and Ampullospira) and three subgenera
   (Globularia, Deshayesia, and Cernina within the genus Globularia).
   Forty-six Cainozoic species revealed residual colour patterns and 29 of
   them, belonging to six genera (Ampullina, Globularia, Crommium,
   Amaurellina, Pachycrommium, Amauropsina), are described herein as
   examples representing the entire diversity of the encountered colour
   patterns. These patterns are most diverse during the Middle Eocene
   coincident with the period of highest taxonomic diversity of the
   Ampullinidae. Four basic classes, regarded as containing possible
   homologous colour patterns in terms of pigments incorporation
   modalities, are proposed. Class I, a fluorescent wide diffuse area or
   spiral stripes, occurs in most of the species, while the three others
   are more peculiar. Class II, fluorescent axial zigzagging stripes, Class
   III, fluorescent axial to slightly opisthocline stripes or segments, and
   Class IV, fluorescent patches forming axial segments by coalescence,
   allow an easy distinction between the genera Globularia, Pachycrommium,
   and three peculiar species of Ampullina. The bauplan of the colour
   patterns revealed in Globularia is very similar to that of the single
   extant species, Globularia (Cernina)fluctuata. This supports the view of
   previous authors who classified them in the same genus. Furthermore, at
   the family level, the peculiar residual patterns belonging to classes
   II, III, and IV have not been observed in naticid gastropods. Thus our
   results for the Cainozoic fossil record are consistent with the
   conclusions based on anatomy and feeding habits, namely that ampullinid
   gastropods, regarded for a long time as belonging to the family
   Naticidae, constitute a family apart.
C1 Caze, Bruno; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Hist Terre, 8 Rue Buffon,CP 38,
   Paris, F-75005, France, France.
EM bruno.caze@mnhn.fr

   position; Colour and luminescence; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Shell; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Geological time periods

DT Article
TI Earliest Jurassic patellogastropod, vetigastropod, and neritimorph
   gastropods from Luxembourg with considerations on the Triassic-Jurassic
   faunal turnover.
AU Monari, Stefano (stefano.monari@unipd.it) 
   Valentini, Mara
   Conti, Maria Alessandra
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 56
IS 2
PS 349-384
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB The Hettangian to earliest Sinemurian Vetigastropoda, Patellogastropoda,
   and Neritimorpha housed in the National Museum of Natural History of
   Luxembourg are studied. Most of the species comes from the Luxembourg
   Sandstone Formation. This deposit formed along the southern margin of
   the London-Brabant-Ardennes Landmass, in a region that during the
   earliest Jurassic constituted a seaway connecting the Paris Basin with
   the epicontinental seas of the Netherlands and northern Germany. The
   systematic analysis revealed high diversity of the studied fauna; we
   identified twenty-two species, eleven genera, nine families, and six
   superfamilies. A new genus, Meiersia gen. nov., and three new species.
   Anodotnaria schroederi sp. nov., Meiersia disarmata sp. nov., and
   Spirocirrus weisi sp. nov. are described. The fauna is dominated by
   pleurotomarioideans representing the genera Ptychomphalus,
   Pleurotomaria, and Trochotoma, and by the patellogastropod genus
   Scurriopsis both in number of species and specimens. The neritimorph
   genus Neridomus is also well represented. Among the accessory taxa,
   Anodomaria and Spirocirrus first appeared in the Late Hettangian of the
   Luxembourg area. Most of these genera show a species radiation in the
   Early Jurassic and are distributed over the western European
   epicontinental shelf, probably favoured by an east to west marine
   transgression which influenced wide areas from the basins of the
   northern Germany to the Paris Basin through the Luxembourg seaway. The
   evolutionary and palaeobiogeographical data demonstrate that this
   radiation was already considerably advanced in the Late Hettangian. This
   suggests that the recovery of the gastropod diversity after the
   end-Triassic crisis was relatively fast in western Europe.
C1 Monari, Stefano; Univ Padua, Dept Geosci, Via Gradenigo 6, Padua,
   I-35131, Italy, Italy.

RI Conti, Mauro/K-7197-2017

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

DT Article
TI A new leanchoiliid megacheiran arthropod from the lower Cambrian Emu Bay
   Shale, South Australia.
AU Edgecombe, Gregory D. (g.edgecombe@nhm.ac.uk) 
   Garcia-Bellido, Diego C.
   Paterson, John R.
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 56
IS 2
PS 385-400
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB The Leanchoiliidae is well-known from abundant material of Leanchoilia,
   from the Burgess Shale and Chengjiang Konservat-Lagerstatten. The first
   Australian member of the group is Oestokerkus megacholix gen. et sp.
   nov., described from the Emu Bay Shale (Cambrian Series 2, Stage 4), at
   Buck Quarry, Kangaroo Island, South Australia, and is intermediate in
   age between the well known leanchoiliid species from the Burgess Shale
   and Chengjiang. Phylogenetic analysis of "short great appendage"
   arthropods (Megacheira) in the context of the chelicerate stem group
   resolves the Australian species as sister to Burgess Shale, Utah, and
   Chengjiang Leanchoilia species, but most readily distinguished from
   Leanchoilia and Alalcomenaeus by a different telson shape, interpreted
   as being forked, widening distally, and with a few dorsally curved
   spines at the posterior angle. Leanchoiliid interrelationships are
   stable to alternative character weights, and Megacheira corresponds to a
   clade in most analyses.
C1 Edgecombe, Gregory D.; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Palaeontol, Cromwell Rd,
   London, SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

   John/0000-0003-2947-3912; Garcia-Bellido, Diego/0000-0003-1922-9836

DT Article
TI Early Norian (Triassic) corals from the Northern Calcareous Alps,
   Austria, and the intra-Norian faunal turnover.
AU Roniewicz, Ewa (eron@twarda.pan.pl) 
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 56
IS 2
PS 401-428
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The first description of early Nodal) coral fauna from the Northern
   Calcareous Alps (Dachstein Plateau and Gosaukamm), Austria, is
   presented: 31 scleractinian species from 24 genera (including three
   corals not formally determined), and three hexanthiniarian species
   belonging to two genera. The stratigraphical position of the main part
   of the fauna discovered in the South Dachstein Plateau at the
   Feisterscharte is determined by means of the conodont Epigondolella
   quadrata (Lacian 1); single finds are from the horizons with
   Epigondolella triangularis and Norigondolella navicula (Lacian 3), and
   one close to the horizon with Epigondolella cf. multidentata (Alaunian
   1). Rare corals from the Gosaukamm are from the Lacian I and Alaunian.
   Five species are described as new: Retiophyllia vesicularis,
   Retiophyllia aranea, Margarosmilia adhios, Hydrasmilia laciana; one new
   genus and species from the family Coryphylliidae, Margarogyra hirsuta;
   one new genus and species, Thamnasterites astreoides, cannot be assigned
   to a family. Two hexanthiniarian species, Pachysolenia cylindrica and
   Pachydendron microthallos, known exclusively from the Tethyan lower
   Norian, represent stratigraphically valuable species. A regularly porous
   coral from the family Microsolenidae, Eocomoseris, which up to now has
   only been known from the Jurassic and Cretaceous, is here identified
   from the Triassic strata (originally described as Spongiomorpha
   (Hexastylopsis) ramosa). Predominant taxa show solitary and phaceloid
   (pseudocolonial) growth forms and an epithecal wall; pennules-bearing
   corals are common. Carnian genera and genera typical of the Lacian and
   Lacian-early Alaunian prevail; a hydrozoan genus Cassianastraea has also
   been encountered as well as a scleractiamorph coral, Furcophyllia
   septafindens). The faunal composition contrasts with that of well known
   late Norian-Rhaetian ones, the difference being observed not only at the
   generic but also at the family level. The post-early Norian change in
   coral spectrum documents the turnover of the coral fauna preceding that
   at the Triassic/Jurassic boundary.

   Poland, Poland.
EM eron@twarda.pan.pl

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

DT Article
TI A new Chinese Mesozoic stick insect.
AU Nel, Andre (anel@mnhn.fr) 
   Delfosse, Emmanuel
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 56
IS 2
PS 429-432
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Renphasma sinica gen. et sp. nov. is described from the Early Cretaceous
   Yixian Formation in Liaoning. It has the general habitus of the Mesozoic
   "stick-insects", with a short thorax, and broad and long tegmina, as
   long as the hind-wings. Its pattern of tegmina venation is typical of
   the Mesozoic Phasmatodea, also present in the Eocene stick insect family
   Gallophasmatidae, viz. archaeorthopteran organisation of median and
   cubital veins. On the other side it has a vomer typical of modern
   Phasmatodea, both supporting the hypothesis that the Mesozoic,
   Cainozoic, and modern stick insects belong to the same clade. The
   pattern of dark and hyaline spots on the wings of Renphasma is probably
   related to mimicry with plants.
C1 Nel, Andre; Museum Natl Hist Nat, CNRS, 45 Rue Buffon, Paris, F-75005,
   France, France.
EM anel@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology

   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Renphasma sinica [Liaoning /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14710072296
DT Article
TI First record of an autochthonous community of fluviatile freshwater
   molluscs from the Middle/Late Miocene Upper Freshwater Molasse (southern
   Germany).
AU Schneider, Simon (s.schneider@lrz.uni-muenchen.de) 
   Prieto, Jerome
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 140
IS 1
PS 1-18
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The discovery of an autochthonous well-preserved assemblage from
   Middle/Late Miocene fluviatile deposits within the Upper Freshwater
   Molasse (Obere Suesswassermolasse) at Hammerschmiede north of Kaufbeuren
   (Allgaeu region, southern Germany) provides the rare opportunity to
   assess both composition and palaeoecology of a typical Miocene northern
   alpine foreland river mollusc community. Three species of bivalves, i.e.
   Margaritifera (Pseudunio) flabellata (GOLDFUSS), Sphaerium (Amesoda)
   rivicola (LAMARCK), and Pisidium (Pisidium) amnicum (PFEIFFER),
   accompanied by the gastropods Borysthenia sp., Bithynia sp. 1, and
   Bithynia sp. 2, are described. The taxonomy of Margaritifera (Pseudunio)
   flabellata is updated, and several nominal subspecies are rejected.
   Sphaerium (Amesoda) rivicola is reported fir the first time from the
   Upper Freshwater Molasse. The eastern to middle European valvatid genus
   Borysthenia is first recorded from the Miocene. Most of these taxa are
   adapted to hard water and a well-oxygenated, sandy fluvial habitat and
   thus provide an excellent example for a common mollusc community of the
   Upper Freshwater Molasse.
C1 Schneider, Simon; Bayer Staatssammlung Palaontol & Geol, Richard Wagner
   Str 10, Munich, D-80333, Germany, Germany.
EM s.schneider@lrz.uni-muenchen.de
OI Schneider, Simon/0000-0001-6493-357X

   Sciences &Ecology

BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Ecology; Habitat; Freshwater
   habitat; Lotic water; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Mollusca [Fossil assemblages / Autochthonous assemblage / Systematics]
   [River /  / ] [Germany / Allgaeu / ] [Miocene / Middle & Late Miocene /
   ]. 
   Sphaerium (Amesoda) rivicola [Germany / Allgaeu, Kaufbeuren,
   Hammerschmiede / new record] [Miocene / Upper Freshwater Molasse / ].

   nassariid and buccinid Gastropoda (Prosobranchia: Nassariidae;
   Buccinidae).
AU Harzhauser, Mathias (mathias.harzhauser@nhm-wien.ac.at) 
   Cernohorsky, Walter

VL 140

PS 29-35
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Several primary homonyms have been discovered for Miocene buccinoid
   gastropods of Europe. Herein we try to clarify these cases by proposing
   available replacement names. For three taxa new replacement names are
   introduced: Nassarius fritzsteiningeri nov. nom., (pro Nassa dispar
   BOETTGER 1902), N. signatodentis nov. nom. (pro Buccinum signatum
   "PARTSCH" HORNES 1852) and N. taurinospeciosus nov. nom. (pro Nassa
   speciosa BELLARDI 1882).

DT Article
TI Two new Napaeus species from La Gomera and La Palma (Canary Islands)
   (Gastropoda: Pulmonata: Enidae).
AU Holyoak, Geraldine A.
   Holyoak, David T.
   Yanes, Yurena
   Alonso, Maria R.
   Ibanez, Miguel (mibanez@ull.es) 
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 140
IS 1
PS 37-48
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of Napaeus are described, from La Gomera and La Palma
   (Canary Islands). Both species are small, that from La Gomera being the
   smallest known Napaeus, its shell surface area (plane view) is more than
   ten times smaller than that of N. bertheloti. The two new species
   actively disguise their shells with lichens and soil, presumably to
   reduce predation.
C1 Ibanez, Miguel; Univ La Laguna, Dept Anim Biol, Tenerife, Canary
   Islands, E-38206, Spain, Spain.

   Atlantic Ocean islands

   Islands, P. 39].

DT Article
TI First records of actual and fossil Stephadiscus outside Patagonia, and
   description of a new Amazonian species (Mollusca: Pulmonata:
   Charopidae).
AU Miquel, Sergio Eduardo (semsnail@macn.gov.ar) 
   Ramirez, Rina
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 140
IS 1
PS 49-56
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB An extension of both temporal and spatial range of Stephadiscus is
   provided, together with the description of the first Amazonian species
   (recorded from Peru) and the first Holocene fossils (found in Chile).
   The new species, S. madrediosensis, was recorded in the Peruvian
   department Madre de Dios. The first Chilean fossils of the genus, which
   would have lived in more humid environmental conditions than at present,
   are recorded from the region of Los Vilos (Choapa province), for the
   late Holocene. Both findings show that the genus Stephadiscus has been
   distributed in the past and at present beyond the limits of the
   Patagonian area.
C1 Miquel, Sergio Eduardo; Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat Bernardino
   Rivadavia, Div Invertebrados, Ave Angel Gallardo 470, Buenos Aires, DF,
   RA-1405, Argentina, Argentina.
EM semsnail@macn.gov.ar

   South America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary

DT Article
TI Revision of the Argnidae, 2. The species of Agardhiella from the eastern
   part of the Balkan Peninsula (Gastropoda: Pulmonata: Pupilloidea).
AU Subai, Peter (subai@bio1.rwth-aachen.de) 
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 140
IS 1
PS 77-116
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The second part of the revision of the Argnidae covers all species of
   the genus Agardhiella living in the eastern part of the distribution
   range. Next to the 11 already known species, 4 new species are
   described: A. domokosi n. sp., A. langaleta n. sp., A. pirotana n. sp.
   and A. serbica n. sp. New records of A. truncatella at the eastern part
   of its distribution range add to the knowledge of this species. Until
   now, the eastern distribution area of species of Agardhiella covers
   Romania, Serbia, the Former Yugoslavian Republic of Macedonia, Bulgaria
   and Northern Greece. Additional records of species of Agardhiella from
   river debris in Hungary and a fossil record from Slovakia are presented.

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Leucostigma A. J. Wagner 1919 (Gastropoda:
   Stylommatophora: Clausiliidae).
AU Nordsieck, Hartmut (hnords@t-online.de) 
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 140
IS 1
PS 123-147
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In this paper a revision of the genus Leucostigma A. J. WAGNER 1919
   based mainly on shell morphology is published. It contains only one
   species, L. candidescens (ROSSMAESSLER 1835), which is distributed in
   central and southern Apennine Italy. The species is subdivided into nine
   subspecies: Leucostigma candidescens candidescens, Leucostigma
   candidescens convertita (FLACH 1907), Leucostigma candidescens
   dextromira n. ssp., Leucostigma candidescens leucostigma (ROSSMAESSLER
   1836), Leucostigma candidescens megachilus (PAULUCCI 1881), Leucostigma
   candidescens monticola n. ssp., Leucostigma candidescens opalina
   (ROSSMAESSLER 1836), Leucostigma candidescens paraconvertita n. ssp.,
   and Leucostigma candidescens samnitica (ROSSMAESSLER 1842). Three of
   these subspecies, Leucostigma candidescens convertita, Leucostigma
   candidescens dextromira n. ssp. and Leucostigma candidescens
   paraconvertita n. ssp., are dextral counterparts of certain normally
   (left-) coiled subspecies. The high diversity within the species is
   described and discussed.

TI New species of the millipede genus Glyphiulus Gervais, 1847 from the
   granulatus-group (Diplopoda: Spirostreptida: Cambalopsidae).
AU Golovatch, S.I.
   Geoffroy, J.-J.
   Mauries, J.-P.
   VandenSpiegel, D.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 20
IS 2
PS 65-114
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The granulatus-group of the basically southeast Asian genus Glyphiulus
   is shown to currently comprise 33 species, of which 13 are new: G.
   grandis sp.n. and G. totalis sp.n. from southern Vietnam, G. difficilis
   sp.n., G. mulunensis sp.n., G. tiani sp.n., G. acutus sp.n., G.
   paramulunensis sp.n., G. proximus sp.n. and G. speobius sp.n., all seven
   from the Mulun karst, Guangxi Province, southern China, all specially
   keyed and mapped because of mostly being very similar to one another, as
   well as G. sattaaa sp.n., G. duangdee sp.n., G. mongkon sp.n. and G.
   maidtree-jit sp.n., all four from Thailand.

PT J
AN ZOOR14710073835
DT Article
TI On synonymy of linyphiid spiders of the Russian fauna (Arachnida:
   Aranei: Linyphiidae). 2.
AU Tanasevitch, Andrei V. (and-tan@mail.ru) 
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 20
IS 2
PS 129-143
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new synonyms are established for the Russian fauna of Linyphiidae:
   Agyneta bialata (Tao, Li et Zhu, 1995), syn.n. = A. birulai
   (Kulczytiski, 1908); Agyneta parasaxatilis Marusik, Hippa et Koponen,
   1996, syn.n. = A. pseudosaxatilis Tanasevitch, 1984; Diplocephalus
   cristatus angusticeps Holm, 1973, syn.n. = D. c. cristatus (Blackwall,
   1833); Minyrioloides trifrons affinis (Schenkel, 1930), syn.n. =M
   trifrons (O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1863); Lepthyphantes tes Marusik, Hippa
   et Koponen, 1996, syn.n. = Oryphantes geminus (Tanasevitch, 1982). The
   synonymy of Bathyphantes biscapus Kulczynski, 1926 with B. humilis (L.
   Koch, 1879), B. simillimus (L. Koch, 1879) with B. eumenis (L. Koch,
   1879) and B. insulanus Holm, 1960 with B. pogonias Kulczynski, 1885, are
   confirmed. The earlier synonymy of B. biscapus and B. keeni (Emerton,
   1917), as well as of B. castor Chamberlin, 1925 and B. pogonias
   Kulczynski 1885, are rejected. The female of B. jeniseicus Eskov, 1979
   is shown to be that of B. eumenis. The female of B. jeniseicus and the
   male of B. humilis are described for the first time. All the records of
   B. iviei Holm, 1970 and B. keeni from Russia are based on
   misidentifications; thus both species are to be excluded from the
   Russian and Palaearctic faunas. Numerous previous misidentifications of
   many species are corrected. Caviphantes pseudosaxetorum Wunderlich, 1979
   is recorded from the Russian fauna for the first time; Gongy-lidiellum
   orduense Wunderlich, 1995, Mecynargus foveatus (Dahl, 1912), Russocampus
   pokhaninovae Tanasevitch, 2004 and Silometopus incurvatus (O.
   Pickard-Cambridge, 1873) are added to the Caucasian fauna; on the
   contrary, G. murcidum Simon, 1884 are to be excluded from the Caucasian
   fauna. The record of Minyrioloides trifrons (O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1863)
   from the Tien-Shang Mts actually refers to M. maritimum Crocker et
   Parker, 1970; the latter species early known as W-European is hence a
   new record to Central Asia..
C1 Tanasevitch, Andrei V.; Russian Acad Sci, Ctr Forest Ecol & Prod,
   Profsoyuznaya Str 84-32, Moscow 117997, Russia, Russia.
EM and-tan@mail.ru
RI Tanasevitch, Andrei/O-7401-2018
OI Tanasevitch, Andrei/0000-0002-9116-606X
SC Zoology
SN 0136-006X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Agyneta pseudosaxatilis [Russia / Komsomolskiy / Natural history]. 
   Agyneta saaristoi [Russia / Khakassian & Buryat / New record]. 
   Agyneta tibialis [Russia / Tuva / New record]. 
   Caviphantes pseudosaxetorum [Russia /  / New record]. 
   Gongylidiellum orduense; Mecynargus foveatus; Russocampus polchaninovae;
   Silometopus incurvatus [Eurasia / Caucasus / New record]. 
   Linyphiidae [Russia /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
   Oryphantes geminus [Russia / Khakassia, Irkutsk & Krasnoyarsk / New
   record].

   (Tao, Li & Zhu 1995), p. 130]. 
   Agyneta pseudosaxatilis - Tanasevitch 1984 (Araneae): [Syn nov, Agyneta
   parasaxatilis Marusik, Hippa Koponen 1996, p. 131]. 
   Agyneta saaristoi (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Agyneta tibialis (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Bathyphantes biscapus - Kulczynski 1926 (Araneae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Bathyphantes keeni (Emerton 1917), p. 134].

   Male, p. 134].

   P. 135]. 
   Bathyphantes keeni - (Emerton 1917) (Araneae): [Removal from synonymy,
   Bathyphantes biscapus Kulczynski 1926, p. 134]. 
   Caviphantes pseudosaxetorum (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Diplocephalus cristatus cristatus - (Blackwall 1833) (Araneae): [Syn
   nov, Diplocephalus cristatus angusticeps Holm 1973, p. 138]. 
   Gongylidiellum orduense (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Linyphiidae (Araneae).

   [Syn nov, Minyrioloides trifrons affinis Schenkel 1930, p. 140]. 
   Oryphantes geminus - Tanasevitch 1982 (Araneae): [Syn nov, Lepthyphantes
   tes Marusik, Hippa & Koponen 1996, p. 141; New record]. 
   Russocampus polchaninovae (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Silometopus incurvatus (Araneae): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14710074989
DT Article
TI The gault of Perthois : burrows, phosphates and small droppings.
FT Le gault du Perthois : terriers, phosphates et petites crottes.
AU Breton, Gerard (gerardbreton@free.fr) 
SO Association Geologique Auboise Bulletin Annuel
VL 31
PS 3-66
PD Juin 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The "Argiles tegulines de Courcelles" Fm are exploited for tile-making
   in two quarries at Pargny-sur-Saulx (Marne) and Contrisson (Meuse),
   between Vitry-le-Francois and Bar-le-Duc. Besides rather common body
   fossils (mainly Molluscs amongst which Ammonites are good stratigraphic
   markers, and Crustaceans), the ichnology of these clayey facies
   ("Gault") is rich and displays a rather good variety of burrows and
   microcoprolites. These trace fossils are generally visible and can be
   studied only when the diagenesis, in peculiar here the phosphatization,
   makes them conspicuous. Several new ichnotaxa are described: Tibikoia
   faecacerva isp. nov., Tomaculopsis tomaculopsis igen. nov., isp. nov.,
   Thoronetia tetrope isp. nov., Octotriangulella caseolus isp. nov.,
   Triplifaex parallela igen. nov., isp. nov., and Podichnus donovani isp.
   nov. If the taphocoenosis of the body fossils provides a good idea of
   the palaeobiodiversity of the Gault in this area, the variety of the
   witnesses of the biological activity: trace fossils, burrows, coprolites
   and one gastrolite gives a different and complementary insight into this
   palaeobiodiversity.
C1 Breton, Gerard; 6 rue des Reservoirs, F-76600 Le Havre, France, France.
EM gerardbreton@free.fr
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0249-0102

PT J
AN ZOOR14710073079
DT Article
TI Taxonomy of the Pacific Swift Apus pacificus Latham, 1802, complex.
AU Leader, Paul J. (pjleader@asiaecol.com.hk) 
SO Bulletin of the British Ornithologists' Club
VL 131
IS 2
PS 81-93
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper considers the taxonomic implications of morphological
   differences within the Pacific Swift Apus pacificus complex. Specimens
   of the four currently recognised subspecies (nominate, kanoi, cooki and
   leuconyx) were examined, plus kurodae (currently treated as a synonym of
   pacificus) and salimali (currently treated as a synonym of kanoi).
   Consistent plumage and structural differences indicate that the current
   taxonomy of the complex is untenable. It is proposed that salimali is a
   valid taxon but that kanoi is not (and should be treated as a junior
   synonym of kurodae) and that pacificus, salimali, leuconyx and cooki
   merit species status.
C1 Leader, Paul J.; Asia Ecol Consultants Ltd, Commercial Ctr 127, Palm
   Springs, Hong Kong, China, China.
EM pjleader@asiaecol.com.hk
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0007-1595
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Biometrics; General morphology;
   Colour and luminescence; Integument; Integumentary derivatives;
   Evolution; Variation
DE Apus pacificus complex [Biometrics / Morphometric variation / Taxonomic
   implications] [General morphology /  / ] [Colour /  / ] [Plumage /  / ]
   [Morphological variation /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Apodiformes, Apodidae
OR Apus pacificus complex (Apodidae). 
   Apus pacificus kurodae - Domaniewski 1933 (Apodidae): [Syn nov, Apus
   pacificus kanoi Yamashina 1942, p. 90].

DT Article
TI [Revision of the subgenus Ochropyga Aurivillius, 1913 (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Lamiinae, Prosopocerini).]
FT Revision du sous-genre Ochropyga Aurivillius, 1913 (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Lamiinae, Prosopocerini).
AU Vitali, Carlo (carlo.vitali38@teletu.it) 
   Vitali, Francesco
SO Cahiers Magellanes
VL 4
PS 23-30
PD Juillet 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The subgenus Ochropyga Aurivillius, 1913 is revised. Prosopocera
   glaucina (Westwood, 1844) is considered as a senior synonym of Ochropyga
   lepesmei Villiers in Lepesme & Villiers, 1941 n. syn. Prosopocera
   ceciliae n. sp. from Cameroon is described. Explanations concerning the
   typical localities and further faunistic data about the other species of
   this subgenus are provided.
C1 Vitali, Carlo; via S. Giorgio 5, I 233010 Postalesio (Sondrio), Italy,
   Italy.
EM carlo.vitali38@teletu.it
SC Zoology
SN 1624-1940

   region; Africa

   Cerambycidae

   24]. 
   Prosopocera ceciliae (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 28]. 
   Prosopocera glaucina - (Westwood 1844) (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov,
   Ochropyga lepesmei Villiers in Lepesme & Villiers 1941, p. 25].

DT Article
TI [Synonymies, diagnoses and bionomy of some African Lamiinae (17th note)
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).]
FT Synonymies, diagnoses et bionomie de quelques Lamiaire africains (17e
   note) (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
AU Teocchi, Pierre
   Sudre, Jerome
   Jiroux, Eric
SO Cahiers Magellanes
VL 4
PS 31-64
PD Juillet 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Informations are given on several species of African Lamiinae.
   Perimonochamus n gen. is described with five new species : Apomecynoides
   linavuorii, Eunidia gracilis n. sp., E. pujoli n. sp., Perimonochatnus
   onorei n. sp., Exocentrus (Pseudocentrus) maleci n. sp. and a new
   subspecies : Prosopocera (hierogyna) argus obydovi n. ssp. Fourteen
   species are synonymized : Prosopocera (Hiergoyna) bomansi Breuning, 1965
   = P. (H.) argus Thomson, 1868; Sophronica Proba Breuning, 1954,S.
   bituberosoides Breuning & Villiers, 1972 et S. metallescens Breuning,
   1978 = S. angusticollis Aurivillius, 1928; S. uniformis Breuning, 1961 &
   S. unicolor Breuning, 1961 = S. costulata Quedenfeldt, 1882; S.
   pararufiniceps Breuning, 1977 = S. rufiniceps Breuning, 1949; S.
   lineatopunctata Pic, 1944 = S rufoscapa Aurivillius, 1907; S.
   striatipennis Breuning, 1952 = S. punctatostriata Breuning, 1948; S.
   nigra Breuning, 1940 & S. paraflavipennis Breuning, 1977 = S. sericans
   Breuning, 1940; S. nigritosuturalis Breuning, 1980 = S. suturella
   Breuning, 1940; Nitakeris fulva (Breuning, 1950) & N. holoflava
   (Breuning, 1956) = N. tibialis Kolbe, 1893.

PT J
AN ZOOR14710075263
DT Article
TI Contribution to the study of longhorns from New Caledonia, II
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Vives, Eduard
   Sudra, Jerome
   Mille, Christian
   Cazeres, Sylvie
SO Cahiers Magellanes
VL 4
PS 65-90
PD Juillet 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In this work, twenty seven species in eight tribes of the Cerambycidae
   family from New Caledonia are revised, and also from the old Fauvel
   collection. Lectotypes of nine species described by Fauvel are
   designated. Eight new genera are described: Serniphoracantha in
   Phoracanthini, Lacordairina, Pseudoceresium and Paralygesis in
   Strongylurini, Montrouzierina and Pseudophlyctaenodes in Phlyctaenodini,
   Calaphneope in Aphneopini, and Caledomicrus in Parmenini. Six new
   species are described: Parahyphus cazeresae, Paralygesis monteithi, P.
   christiani, Pseudophlyctyaenodes doi, Calaphneope monteithi and
   Caledomicrus mimeticus. Fourteen new nomenclatural combinations are
   proposed for species described by Montrouzier, Belon, Perroud and
   Fauvel. Finally, we also establish the synonymy of Phoracantha saviesi
   Fauvel, 1906, and Phoracantha triangularis Carter, 1929.
C1 Vives, Eduard; Museu de Zoologia de Barcelona, Passeig Picasso s/n, P.O.
   Box 593, Spain, Spain.
SC Zoology
SN 1624-1940
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Combination; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Land zones; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands

   Cerambycidae [New Caledonia /  / Taxonomic revision].

PT J
AN ZOOR14710072249
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Two new species of cobitid fish (Teleostei, Cobitidae) from the River
   Nanliu and the River Beiliu, China.
AU Chen, Yongxia (chenyongxia@hbu.edu.cn) 
   Chen, Yifeng
SO Folia Zoologica
VL 60
IS 2
PS 143-152
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species of Cobitis, C. multimaculata sp. nov. and C.
   microcephala sp. nov. are described and illustrated from the River
   Nanliu and the River Beiliu, Guangxi Province, China. Cobitis
   multimaculata can be distinguished from congeners by its unique colour
   pattern of scattered, small, elongated, oval blotches on the side of the
   body; well developed mental lobes; and cardioid lamina circularis. It is
   similar to C. arenae, but can be distinguished from it by possessing a
   stumpy body (body depth 6.1-6.6 in standard length in males and 5.7-7.3
   in females versus 7.9 in standard length in male and 7.3-9.6 in
   females), shorter caudal peduncle (caudal peduncle depth 1.4-1.7 of its
   length in males and 1.6-1.8 in females versus 2.5 in male and 2.3-3.1 in
   females); and 17-22 small, elongate oval blotches along lateral line
   (versus 20-25 spots). Cobitis microcephala can be distinguished from
   congeners by possessing small and solitary irregular spots scattered on
   the side of the body; a slender and finely serrated (16-18 serrae on the
   inner margin) lamina circularis; and a much smaller jet black spot on
   upper half of caudal-fin base.
C1 Chen, Yongxia; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Hydrobiol, Wuhan, Hubei Province
   430072, China, China.
EM chenyongxia@hbu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0139-7893
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Cobitis [China /  / Key to species]. 
   Cobitis microcephala; Cobitis multimaculata [Guangxi Zhuang /  / New
   species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

   Cypriniformes, Cobitidae

PT J
AN ZOOR14710077661
DT Article
TI Totoralia, a new conical-shaped mollusk from the Middle Cambrian of
   western Argentina.
AU Tortello, M.F. (tortello@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Sabattini, N.M.
SO Geologica Acta
VL 9
IS 2
PS 175-185
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The new genus Totoralia from the late middle Cambrian of El Totoral
   (Mendoza Province, western Argentina) is described herein. It is a
   delicate, high, bilaterally symmetrical cone with a sub-central apex and
   five to seven prominent comarginal corrugations. In addition, its
   surface shows numerous fine comarginal lines, as well as thin, closely
   spaced radial lirae. Totoralia gen. nov., in most respects, resembles
   the Cambrian helcionellids Scenella Billings and Palaeacmaea Hall and
   Whitfield. Although Scenella has been considered as a chondrophorine
   cnidarian by some authors in the past, now the predominant view is that
   it is a mollusk. Likewise, several aspects of Totoralia gen. nov.
   morphology indicate closer affinities with mollusks. The specimens
   studied constitute elevated cones that are rather consistent in height,
   implying that they were not flexible structures like those of the
   chondrophorines. The presence of a short concave slope immediately in
   front of the apex can also be interpreted as a mollusk feature. In
   addition, the numerous comarginal lines of the cone are uniform in
   prominence and constant in spacing, and are only represented on the
   dorsal surface of the shell; thus, they are most similar to the
   incremental growth lines of shells of mollusks. The morphology of
   Totoralia gen. nov. is regarded as primitive in the Helcionelloida
   because the ancestor of the class is likely to have had a minute,
   untorted limpet-shaped shell. Although the new genus herein described
   seems to be endemic to Argentina, the Cambrian occurrences of related
   scenellid genera suggest affinities with Laurentia.
C1 Tortello, M.F.; CONICET-Division Paleozoologia Invertebrados, Museo de
   La Plata, Paseo del Bosque s/n, 1900 La Plata, Argentina, Argentina.
EM tortello@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Zoology
SN 1695-6133
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Totoralia [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Archaeogastropoda,
   Helcionelloidea
OR Totoralia (Mollusca): [Gen nov, Of family Scenellidae, Type species
   Pichynella? hornillensis Rusconi 1956, p. 178, Cambrian; Fossil]. 
   Totoralia hornillensis - (Rusconi 1956) (Mollusca): [Redescription, P.
   179; Comb nov, Transferred from Pichynella, p. 179; Syn nov, Pichynella
   striata Rusconi 1958, p. 180; Fossil]. 
   Pichynella? hornillensis - Rusconi 1956 (Helcionelloidea): [Designated
   type species for new genus, Totoralia, p. 178; Fossil].

AN ZOOR14710071308
DT Article
TI A late Burdigalian bathyal mollusc fauna from the Vienna Basin
   (Slovakia).
AU Harzhauser, Mathias (mathias.harzhauser@nhm-wien.ac.at) 
   Mandic, Oleg
   Schloegl, Jan
SO Geologica Carpathica
VL 62
IS 3
PS 211-231
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB This is the first record of a bathyal mollusc fauna from the late Early
   Miocene of the Central Paratethys. The assemblage shows clear affinities
   to coeval faunas of the Turin Hills in the Mediterranean area and the
   Aquitaine Basin in France. The overall biostratigraphic value of the
   assemblage is hard to estimate due to the general very poor knowledge of
   Miocene bathyal faunas. Several species, however, are known from deep
   water deposits of the Middle Miocene Badenian stage as well. This
   implies Early Miocene roots of parts of the Middle Miocene deep water
   fauna and suggests a low turnover for bathyal mollusc communities at the
   Early-Middle Miocene boundary. The nassariid gastropod Nassarius
   janschloegli Harzhauser nov. sp. and the naticid gastropod Polinices
   cerovaensis Harzhauser nov. sp. are introduced as new species.
C1 Harzhauser, Mathias; Nat Hist Museum Vienna, Burgring 7, Vienna, A-1010,
   Austria, Austria.
EM mathias.harzhauser@nhm-wien.ac.at

DT Article
TI Revised conodont zonation and conodont evolution across the
   Permian-Triassic boundary at the Shangsi section, Guangyuan, Sichuan,
   South China.
AU Jiang, Haishui
   Lai, Xulong (xllai@cug.edu.cn) 
   Yan, Chunbo
   Aldridge, Richard J.
   Wignall, Paul
   Sun, Yadong
SO Global and Planetary Change
VL 77
IS 3-4
PS 103-115
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 27
AB Large conodont samples (20 kg at most) have been collected from the
   uppermost Permian and the lowermost Triassic (beds 26-33) at Shangsi,
   northern Sichuan. These have enabled us to establish parallel hindeodid
   and gondolellid conodont zones through the section similar to previously
   recognized in the Meishan section. In ascending order, three newly
   established gondolellid zones at the Shangsi section are: Neogondolella
   yini Zone (bed 26), Neogondolella meishanensis Zone (beds 27a-27c),
   Neogondolella taylorae Zone (beds 28a-29 d). Also in ascending order,
   four revised or newly established hindeodid zones are: Hindeodus
   changyingensis Zone (beds 28a-29b) Hindeodus parvus Zone (beds 29c-30a),
   Isarcicella lobata Zone (beds 30b-31a), Isarcicella isarcica Zone (bed
   31b and above). According to the new data, the first occurrence of H.
   parvus is about 2 m lower than the previously reported horizon. On the
   basis of both hindeodid and gondolellid taxa, the PTB is placed 22 cm
   above the base of bed 28a. This conodont zonation of the Shangsi section
   will help improve correlations of global Permian-Triassic boundary
   sections. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Lai, Xulong; China Univ Geosci, Minist Educ, Wuhan, Hubei, 430074,
   China, China.
EM xllai@cug.edu.cn
RI Sun, Yadong/AAG-8781-2019; Sun, Yadong/N-6907-2013
OI Sun, Yadong/0000-0003-4032-2082; Sun, Yadong/0000-0003-4032-2082; Lai,
   Xulong/0000-0002-2837-0885
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0921-8181
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic; Palaeozoic
DE Conodonta [Sichuan / Shangsi / stratigraphical distribution;
   systematics] [Triassic / Permian-Triassic boundary / ] [Permian /  / ]. 
   Isarcicella huckriedei [Sichuan /  / new species] [ /  / ] [Triassic / 
   / ] [Permian /  / ]. 
TN Conodonts; Invertebrates

OR Conodonta (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
   Isarcicella huckriedei - Lai & Jiang 2011 (Conodonta): [Sp nov, Sichuan,
   Permian, P. 112; Fossil].

TI Description of a new species of Vexillum (Costellaria) (Gastropoda:
   Costellariidae) from western Australia.
AU Dekkers, Aart M. (aart.dekkers@wxs.nl) 
SO Gloria Maris
VL 50
IS 3-4
PS 52-59
PD juni 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB It is argued that the western Australian morph mostly known under the
   name of Vexillum (Costellaria) zebuense (Reeve, 1844) has to be regarded
   as a nominal taxon. The new species is named Vexillum (Costellaria)
   johnwattsi sp. nov. and thoroughly compared with Vexillum (Costellaria)
   zebuense (Reeve, 1844), Vexillum (Costellaria) dohrni (A. Adams, 1864)
   and Vexillum (Costellaria) ismene Turner, 2008. The new species is only
   known from western Australia.

   (Buccinidae, Gastropoda) in the Cape Verde Archipelago, with the
   description of Euthria emilioi sp. nov.

   Afonso, Carlos M.L.

VL 50
IS 3-4
PS 83-92
PD juni 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Specimens of shallow water Euthria collected on Sal and Boavista Islands
   in the Cape Verde Archipelago are studied. Several new populations of E.
   taeniopsoides Fraussen & Afonso, 2009 with striking different colours
   are recorded from the east coast of Sal Island. Orange and yellow
   coloured shells from Boavista Island similar to E. calderoni Rolan, 1985
   and previously recorded by Rolan (1987: 304-307, fig 9a) are 11
   concluded to belong to a distinct species, which is described herein and
   added to the fauna of the Cape Verde Archipelago as E. emilioi sp. nov.

PT J
AN ZOOR14710071394
DT Article
TI Insights From Whaling Logbooks on Whales, Dolphins, and Whaling in the
   Gulf of Mexico.
AU Reeves, Randall R.
   Lund, Judith N.
   Smith, Tim D.
   Josephson, Elizabeth A.
SO Gulf of Mexico Science
VL 29
IS 1
PS 41-67
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Whaling voyage logbooks provide a unique window into historical marine
   animal distribution and relative numbers. The Gulf of Mexico was among
   the regions visited by American commercial whalers beginning in the late
   1700s, and possibly as early as the 1760s. For more than a century, they
   hunted sperm whales (Physeter macrocephalat) and blackfish (usually
   probably short-ruined pilot whales; Globicephala macrorhynchus) in the
   Gulf. An ongoing study of global whaling history has allowed us to offer
   some insights on characteristics and trends of the Gulf fishery and on
   cetacean populations in the Gulf. We examined 53 voyage logbooks that
   included some whaling in the Gulf. Using the information from those
   logbooks and other sources, we identified 204 different voyages that
   included one or more "vessel-seasons" of whaling in the Gulf (total of
   214 vessel. seasons) between 1788 and 1877. More than three-quarters
   (76%) of the 186 voyages for which the rig type is known were by brigs
   or schooners; they sailed primarily from the Massachusetts ports of New
   Bedford and Nantucket initially and Provincetown in later years. The
   whaling took place mainly in deep portions of the Gulf and in the first
   7 mo of the calendar year (i.e., from Jan. through July). The sperm
   whales hunted in the Gulf tended to be small and were usually taken from
   schools, suggesting that they were mostly juveniles and females.
   Observations (and occasionally catches) of other cetaceans besides sperm
   whales and blackfish are mentioned in the logbooks-mainly "finbacks"
   (Balaenoptera sp.), killer whales (Orcinus orca), and "porpoises"
   (various small delphinids).
C1 Reeves, Randall R.; Okapi Wildlife Associates, 27 Chandler Lane, Hudson,
   PQ, J0P 1H0, Canada, Canada.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1087-688X
BD Animals and man; Disturbance by man; Commercial activities; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Cetacea [Whaling / Historical whaling trips / ] [Gulf of Mexico /  / ]. 
TN Cetaceans; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia
OR Cetacea (Mammalia). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14710071394
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14710073518
DT Article
TI Bittium nanum (Gastropoda, Cerithiidae), a valid species from the Azores
   Islands.
FT Bittium nanum (Gastropoda, Cerithiidae), una especie valida de las islas
   Azores.
AU Moreno, Diego
SO Iberus
VL 29
IS 1
PS 59-74
PD junio 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A redescription is given for the species of the genus Bittium Gray, 1847
   which is one of the most abundant components of the zoobenthos on rocky
   shores of the Azores. The species has been confused by almost all
   authors with the European species B. reticulatum (da Costa, 1778) or B.
   latreillii (Payraudeau, 1826) but differs enough to be considered a
   species endemic to the archipelago. It is proposed to use for this
   species the binomen Bittium nanum (Mayer, 1864), a forgotten but
   nomenclaturally valid name based on fossils of a terrace of Pleistocene
   age in Prainha, Island of Santa Maria. This name (first introduced in
   the binomen Cerithiopsis nana Mayer, 1864) is a primary homonym of
   Cerithiopsis tubercularis var. none Jeffreys, 1867, which should be
   renamed or better described anew.
C1 Moreno, Diego; Apartamentos Las Dunas 2, Cabo De Gata, Almeria, 04150,
   Spain, Spain.
SC Zoology
SN 0212-3010
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda,
   Cerithioidea, Cerithiopsoidea
OR Bittium nanum - (Mayer 1864) (Cerithioidea): [Redescription, P. 62; Comb
   nov, Transferred from Cerithiopsis, p. 61]. 
   Cerithiopsis nana - Mayer 1864 (Cerithiopsoidea): [Referred to, Bittium,
   p. 61]. 
   Cerithiopsis tubercularis var. nana - Jeffreys 1867 (Cerithiopsoidea):
   [Homonymy, P. 71].

PT J

DT Article
TI Two new species and a new record of biting midges from Emei Mountain,
   China (Ceratopogonidae, Diptera).
AU Deng, Cheng-Yu
   Liao, Zhong-You
   Zhang, You-Zhi
   Mo, Dong-Ping

VL 18
IS 2
PS 115-119
PD Jun 2011

U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper deals with two new species and a new record of biting
   midges from Mt. Emei, Emei County, Sichuan Province, China. All
   specimens were collected with net trap (luring Sept. 15-29, 2010 from
   Mt. Emei (29. 5[degree]N, 103. 3[degree]E), Sichuan Province, and are
   deposited in the Collection of Medical Entomology of Beijing Institution
   of Microbiology and Epidemiology (20 Dongdajie Ave., Fengtai Dis.,
   Beijing 100071, China).

TI THE FIRST ATTEMPT ON SUBGENERIC COMPOSITION OF CHLOROPHORUS CHEVROLAT,
   1863 WITH FOUR NEW SUBGENERA (COL.: CERAMBYCIDAE: CERAMBYCINAE).
AU Ozdikmen, Huseyin (ozdikmen@gazi.edu.tr) 
SO Munis Entomology & Zoology
VL 6
IS 2
PS 535-539
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The paper gives the first attempt on subgeneric composition of
   Chlorophorus Chevrolat, 1863. As a result of this, a total of 5
   subgenera (including the nominotypical subgenus) are described for the
   world fauna as Chlorophorus (s. str.) Chevrolat, 1863; Chlorophorus
   (Immaculatus) subgen. n.; Chlorophorus (Perderomaculatus) subgen. n.;
   Chlorophorus (Humeromaculatus) subgen. n. and Chlorophorus
   (Crassofasciatus) subgen. n.. The type species of new taxa are figured.
   A key for subgenera is also given in the text.

DT Article
TI Myxobolus lalbaghensis sp. n. from a freshwater fish of West Bengal,
   India.
AU Banerjee, Sayani
   Bandyopadhyay, Probir K. (prabir0432@hotmail.com) 
   Gocmen, Bayram
   Mitra, Amlan Kumar
SO North-Western Journal of Zoology
VL 7
IS 1
PS 1-4
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Myxobolus Buetschli 1882 (Myxozoa, Myxosporea, Bivalvulida, Myxobolidae)
   is an important parasitic protozoan of freshwater fishes reported from
   almost all over the world. The severity of infection may lead to
   mortality of fish host. The present paper deals with the description of
   a new species of Myxobolus Buetschli 1882, Myxobolus lalbaghensis sp. n.
   from a freshwater food fish Labeo bata (Hamilton, 1822) from the state
   of West Bengal, India.
C1 Bandyopadhyay, Probir K.; Parasitology Laboratory, Department of
   Zoology, University of Kalyani, Kalyani-741235, West Bengal, India,
   India.

DT Article
TI The myrmecofauna (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) of Hungary: an updated
   checklist.
AU Csosz, Sandor (csosz@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu) 
   Marko, Balint
   Galle, Laszlo
SO North-Western Journal of Zoology
VL 7
IS 1
PS 55-62
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The last checklist of Hungarian myrmecofauna was published at the end of
   the 1990s. Since then, several taxonomic and faunistic changes have
   occurred. The following article provides an updated checklist of
   Hungarian ants containing 126 species, five of which are found
   exclusively indoors. Six new species of the Hungarian myrmecofauna are
   reported (Temnothorax albipennis, T. jailensis, Tetramorium sp. D,
   Tapinoma melanocephalum, Plagiolepis pallescens, and P. ampeloni), and a
   few species are deleted from the list. Finally, we offer a brief
   descriptive comparison of the Hungarian myrmecofauna with the ant fauna
   of the surrounding countries.
C1 Csosz, Sandor; Hymenoptera Collection, Hungarian Natural History Museum,
   str. Baross 13, 1088 Budapest, Hungary, Hungary.
EM csosz@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu

TI A new Lycian Salamander, threatened with extinction, from the Goynuk
   Canyon (Antalya, Anatolia), Lyciasalamandra irfani n. sp. (Urodela:
   Salamandridae).
AU Gocmen, Bayram (cypriensis@yahoo.com) 
   Arikan, Huseyin
   Yalcinkaya, Deniz
SO North-Western Journal of Zoology
VL 7
IS 1
PS 151-160
PD June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of the Lycian Salamander, Lyciasalamandra irfani n. sp. is
   described and its relation with similar previously known taxa is
   discussed. The new species characterized by having rather darkly
   coloured head part and also an aubergine reddish brown ground colour on
   dorsum with irregularly scattered white flecks. It originates from
   Goynuk Canyon (Antalya) in southwestern Anatolia. At present, the
   distribution is limited to its type locality. Some information is added
   in regard to its habitat.

DT Article
TI Composition and classification of insect damage on Nothofagus glauca
   (Fagaceae), Maule Region, Chile.
FT Composicion y clasificacion de dano de insectos en Nothofagus glauca
   (Fagaceae), Region del Maule, Chile.
AU Huerta Fuentes, Amanda (ahuertaf@gmail.com) 
   Navarrete Valdivia, Wilson
   Araya Clericus, Jaime
   Munoz Alegria, Francisco
SO Revista Colombiana de Entomologia
VL 37
IS 1
PS 56-61
PD Junio 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Maulino forest, where the "hualo", Nothofagus glauca, dominates, is
   one of the Chilean plant formations least studied for its entomological
   fauna. This endemic tree of Chile is distributed from the regions of
   Metropolitana and Bio-Bio, in environments very fragmented by
   deforestation in previous decades and by the introduction of exotic
   trees. The assessment of damage by insects is a necessary tool for
   decision-making about integrated pest management. Given the scarce
   knowledge in this matter on this species, periodical samplings were made
   of foliage, bark, wood, fruits and roots and insect collections
   associated with N. glauca during the 2001-2002,2002-2003, and 2003-2004
   spring-summer seasons to analyze their insect composition and classify
   their damage, in second growth sectors located in Empedrado County,
   Maule Region, Chile. The insects associated with N. glauca were grouped
   in three orders, 13 families and 25 species, predominantly coleopterans
   (seven families, 19 species), followed by lepidopterans (three families,
   three species) and hemipterans (three families, three species). Foliage
   insects were the most abundant (16 species), causing moderate damage,
   followed by those on wood and bark, with seven and six species each, two
   of which caused significant damage. Of the species found, eight are new
   records for N. glauca, with five extending the geographical distribution
   toward the north of the country. Nearly 60% of collected fruits
   presented damage by Perzelia sp. (Lepidoptera: Oecophoridae), an insect
   that affects the regenerative processes of N. glauca.
C1 Huerta Fuentes, Amanda; Univ Chile, Fac Ciencias Forestales & Conservac
   Nat, Casilla 9206, Santiago, Chile, Chile.
EM ahuertaf@gmail.com
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0120-0488
BD Nutrition; Diet; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Insecta [Food plants / Nothofagus glauca / New record; records] [Plant
   hosts /  / ] [Chile / Metropolitana & Bio Bio / ] [ /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda
OR Insecta (Arthropoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14710071629
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14710071645

TI Three new species of Enicospilus (Ichneumonidae: Ophioninae) from
   Colombia.
FT Tres especies nuevas de Enicospilus (Ichneumonidae: Ophioninae) de
   Colombia.
AU Garcia Garcia, Alexander (alexgarcia45@hotmail.com) 
SO Revista Colombiana de Entomologia
VL 37
IS 1
PS 145-151
PD Junio 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 3
AB Three species of parasitoid wasps of the genus Enicospilus (Ophioninae:
   Ichneumonidae) are described; these were found after a revision of
   specimens deposited in the entomological collections of Colombia. The
   species were collected in the municipalities of Chiquinquira (Boyaca),
   Tocaima (Cundinamarca) and the National Natural Park La Paya (Putumayo).
   Each taxon has information on morphological and morphometrical
   variation, as well as their distribution in Colombia.
C1 Garcia Garcia, Alexander; Univ Dist Franscisco Jose de Caldas, Proyecto
   Curricular Licenciatura Biol, Bogota, Colombia, Colombia.

DT Article
TI Revision of Hermodice Kinberg, 1857 (Polychaeta: Amphinomidae).
AU Yanez-Rivera, Beatriz (beyariv7@gmail.com) 
   Salazar-Vallejo, Sergio I.
SO Scientia Marina
VL 75
IS 2
PS 251-262
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The genus Hermodice Kinberg, 1857 was established with the species
   Aphrodita carunculata Pallas, 1766, based on the shape and development
   of the caruncle. Several species were later described within the genus;
   however, it is currently regarded as monotypical, with H. carunculata as
   a widespread species. An evaluation of available type and non-type
   specimens together with observations of living specimens has allowed the
   diagnostic features to be refined, and two new features have been
   included: the number of branchial filaments and the anal lobe.
   Consequently, in this study we have been able to confirm the differences
   between Hermodice and Pherecardia Horst, 1886. The type species, H.
   carunculata, has been redescribed, and H. nigrolineata Baird, 1870 has
   been re-established. Further, H. formosa (Quatrefages, 1866) has been
   transferred to Pherecardia, together with H. pennata Treadwell, 1906 and
   H. distincta Hoagland, 1920.
C1 Yanez-Rivera, Beatriz; Colegio Frontera Sur, Unidad Chetumal, Av
   Centenario Km 5-5, Chetumal, Quintana Roo 77900, Mexico, Mexico.
EM beyariv7@gmail.com
RI Yanez Rivera, Beatriz/G-1921-2019
OI Yanez Rivera, Beatriz/0000-0002-3192-2142
SC Zoology
SN 0214-8358

   Synonymy; Unavailable name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Hermodice - Kinberg 1857 (Polychaeta): [Emended diagnosis, P. 255; Key
   to species, P. 261]. 
   Hermodice bruguieresi - (Quatrefages 1866) (Polychaeta): [Referred to,
   Pherecardia, p. 256]. 
   Hermodice carunculata - (Pallas 1766) (Polychaeta): [Redescription, P.
   256; Removal from synonymy, Hermodice nigrolineata Baird 1870, p. 259]. 
   Hermodice formosa - (Quatrefages 1866) (Polychaeta): [Referred to,
   Pherecardia, p. 256]. 
   Hermodice nigrolineata - Baird 1870 (Polychaeta): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Hermodice carunculata (Pallas 1766), p. 259]. 
   Hermodice pennata - Treadwell 1906 (Polychaeta): [Referred to,
   Pherecardia, p. 256]. 
   Hermodice pennata tutuliensis - Treadwell 1926 (Polychaeta): [Referred
   to, Pherecardia, p. 256]. 
   Hermodice picta - Kinberg 1867 (Polychaeta): [Nomen nudum, P. 256]. 
   Pherecardia bruguieresi - (Quatrefages 1866) (Polychaeta): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Hermodice, p. 256]. 
   Pherecardia formosa - (Quatrefages 1866) (Polychaeta): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Hermodice, p. 256]. 
   Pherecardia pennata - (Treadwell 1906) (Polychaeta): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Hermodice, p. 256]. 
   Pherecardia pennata tutuliensis - (Treadwell 1926) (Polychaeta): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Hermodice, p. 256].

DT Article
TI The butterflies fauna of subfamily Satyrinae of the Ampay massif (Peru):
   diversity, endemism and conservation (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae).
FT La fauna de mariposas de la subfamilia Satyrinae del macizo del Ampay
   (Peru): diversidad, endemismo y conservacion (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae).
AU Pyrcz, T.W. (pyrcztomasz@hotrnail.com) 
   Viloria, A.L.
   Lamas, G.
   Boyer, P.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 39
IS 154
PS 205-232
PD Jun 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 7
AB The first faunal inventory of Satyrinae butterflies of the subtribes
   Pronophilina and Erebiina is presented for the Ampay massif (Apurimac,
   Peru). It comprises 19 species, a low value compared to other sampled
   areas of the Andes in Peru. The low local diversity is possibly due to
   the relative isolation of the Ampay massif, and the small area of cloud
   forests, main habitat of most butterflies studied, restricted to patches
   within a narrow 2800-3600 m altitude band. However, the ratio of
   endemism is high. Eight new taxa are described, six of which are endemic
   to Ampay. A short comparative study fauna of Ampay and the Sierra Nevada
   de Santa Marta is presented. Similarity to the fauna of Machu Picchu is
   also evaluated. It is suggested to enlarge the Ampay National Sanctuary
   to the northern slopes of the massif in order to preserve three
   geographically extremely restricted endemic taxa found in that area.
C1 Pyrcz, T.W.; Uniwersytetu Jagiellonskiego, Muzeum Zool, Ul Ingardena 6,
   Krakow, PL-30060, Poland, Poland.
EM pyrcztomasz@hotrnail.com
OI Lamas, Gerardo/0000-0002-3664-6730
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation;
   Forestry
SN 0300-5267

   within habitat; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Abiotic factors; Physical
   factors; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

   karsholti; Pedaliodes llorenteana [Peru /  / New species].

   monachella adamsiella [Peru /  / New subspecies].

   [Forest and woodland / Cloud forest / faunal list] [Altitude /  / ]
   [Peru / Apurimac, Ampay massif / ].

   Papilionoidea, Nymphalidae
